name: Media Releases
description:
This data represents a central collection of Public Service Announcements (PSA), News Releases and Media Advisories for all to search and review.  Dataset will be refreshed at approximately 13:00 and 17:00 each weekday.

Disclaimer:

The Release Body Part 1 and Part 2 columns are intended to provide text search capabilities and is by no means intended to reflect the full Media Release.  For the official media release, please refer to the Release URL.
purpose: To provide citizens a means to review all public communications from the City of Edmonton to the public.

columns.name: date issued
columns.description: The date that the Media Release was released to the public.

columns.name: type of release
columns.description: The type of release is restricted to being PSA (Public Service Announcement), Media Advisory or News Release.

columns.name: headline
columns.description: The headline of the Media Release.

columns.name: release url
columns.description: The web (internet) URL path to where the official Media Release document can be found.

columns.name: release body part 1
columns.description: The first 5,000 characters of the Media Release body.

columns.name: release body part 2
columns.description: If the Media Release extends beyond 5,000; the second 5,000 characters of the Media Release body.

columns.name: release body part 3
columns.description: If the Media Release extends beyond 10,000; the third 5,000 characters of the Media Release body.

columns.name: release body part 4
columns.description: If the Media Release extends beyond 15,000; the fourth 5,000 characters of the Media Release body.

name: 2012 Census - Population by Citizenship (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2012. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: Developer Arterial Projects
description: When an independent developer begins a residential or commercial project they also develop the roadways to accommodate any traffic impact from the future development. These projects are funded and managed exclusively by the developer. It is the City of Edmonton’s responsibility to ensure the developers are complying with the approved standards and specifications.
purpose: To display the developer arterial projects in Edmonton.  The projects listed are in various stages of planning.

At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 3130 Insight Community Members. 1296 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 41%. name: Edmontonians' Perception Survey - Park Usage
description:
In 2014, the City of Edmonton contracted Leger to conduct a survey of Edmontonians designed to understand perceptions on key measures relating to the quality of life in Edmonton.

This research is aimed at capturing citizen perception based performance measures which feed into the corporate performance reporting to achieve the City’s vision for 2040 (The Way Ahead). In recent years, Citizen Perception Surveys have been carried out annually to gather data and report on the measures. 

Taking into account the recent modifications in performance measures as well as the focus on continuous improvement, the 2014 research was designed to: 
- Measure the progress with respect to the key performance measures
- Understand the drivers of the performance measures and provide recommendations about how the measures can be further improved.
- Make comparisons with past measures wherever applicable

name: Insight Community App - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the July 2015 Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=417&t=1. Open from July 13 - 21, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 3130 Insight Community Members. 1296 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 41%. A total of 1348 respondents completed the survey: 1296 Insight Community Members and 52 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

columns.name: q40_insight_app
columns.description: Single response question,The Office of Public Engagement is always looking for ways to improve your experience as an Insight Community member.  We strive to make providing input convenient for you. We are exploring the possibility of asking Edmonton Insight Community members to download a smartphone app. This app would notify you of new items posted to the Insight Community. It can also send you surveys based on your location, if you choose to enable that feature. For example, if you were walking out of a recreation facility the app may send you a notification asking about your experience. This app would use the location of your smartphone for notifications, similar to a 'find your phone' app or mapping tool. If this app was available, would you download and use it? || Possible Answers: Yes/No/I don’t know

name: 2009 Census - Dwelling Unit By Structure Type And Ownership (Ward)
description:
All Census information is as of April 1, 2009.
Ward Reports are based on the 6-Ward system, which existed in the City of Edmonton until October, 2010.
No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city-, ward- and neighbourhood-level only.
The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.
Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information can not be obtained (i.e. information is not available or can not be released by the facility administration).
“Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Census information is used by every municipal department, as well as a wide variety of external agencies, to assist with the planning and delivery of programs and services for the citizens of Edmonton.  This report shows the number of households in the region, grouped by the type of structure and whether the unit is owned or rented.

columns.description: Ward Reports are based on the 6-Ward system, which existed in the City of Edmonton until October, 2010.

columns.description: Number of household units where the ownership status was not available.

name: Bike Safety - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the November 2015 Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=641&as=972dH6O71T&t=1. Open from November 9 - 17, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 3980 Insight Community Members. 1797 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 45%. A total of 1914 respondents completed the survey: 1797 Insight Community Members and 117 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

name: 2014 Census - Dwelling Unit Status (Ward)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring. name: 2012 Census - Dwelling Unit Status (Neighbourhood)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2012. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: 2014 Census - Dwelling Unit By Ownership (Neighbourhood)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014.  Ages of residents are effective April 1, 2014.  No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information cannot be obtained (i.e. information is not available or cannot be released by the facility administration).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: Emergency Preparedness and Communications - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the April Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=254&t=1. Open from April 14 - 22, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to *** Insight Community Members. 947 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 41%. A total of 979 respondents completed the survey: 947 Insight Community Members and 32 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

name: Edmontonians' Perception Survey - Safety In The City
description:
In 2014, the City of Edmonton contracted Leger to conduct a survey of Edmontonians designed to understand perceptions on key measures relating to the quality of life in Edmonton.

This research is aimed at capturing citizen perception based performance measures which feed into the corporate performance reporting to achieve the City’s vision for 2040 (The Way Ahead). In recent years, Citizen Perception Surveys have been carried out annually to gather data and report on the measures. 

Taking into account the recent modifications in performance measures as well as the focus on continuous improvement, the 2014 research was designed to: 
- Measure the progress with respect to the key performance measures
- Understand the drivers of the performance measures and provide recommendations about how the measures can be further improved.
- Make comparisons with past measures wherever applicable

name: Waste Management Services - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the May Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=310&t=1. Open from May 11 - 19, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2,709 Insight Community Members. 1115 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 41%. A total of 1210 respondents completed the survey: 1115 Insight Community Members and 95 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

name: 2014 Census - Population By Marital Status (Neighbourhood)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: 2012 Census - Population By Length of Residence (Neighbourhood)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2012. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: Property Assessment Data (2012 - 2016)
description:
This dataset contains the historical assessed value of properties within the City of Edmonton. It is effective from January 1st, 2012 until December 31st, 2016.

The information is collected for property assessment interpretation purposes only. 

The City of Edmonton does not warrant or guarantee the completeness and accuracy of the information presented. 
The City of Edmonton does not assume responsibility nor accept any liability arising from any use of the information other than for property assessment interpretation.

name: Exercise Habits - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the March Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=219&t=1. Open from March 9 - 17, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2351 Insight Community Members. 1137 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 48%. A total of 1205 respondents completed the survey: 1137 Insight Community Members and 68 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

columns.name: current_exercise_routine_q1
columns.description:
Single response question. Respondents were asked to select a response. Question: How many times per week do you exercise? By exercise, we mean any specific recreation or fitness activities like swimming, jogging, sports, yoga, aerobics, golf, etc. other than daily routine activities (for example, climbing stairs at home, walking the dog, walking to a shop or walking to transit) || Possible Answers: Not at all\Once a week or less\
2-3 times a week\4-5 times week\More than 5 times week

name: 2012 Census - Dwelling Unit By Ownership (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2012.  Ages of residents are effective April 1, 2012.  No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information cannot be obtained (i.e. information is not available or cannot be released by the facility administration).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: Development Notif Letters - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the December Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=141&t=1. Open from November 30 - December 09, 2014. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2035 Insight Community Members. 950 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 47%. A total of 1049 respondents completed the survey: 950 Insight Community Members and 99 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

name: Measuring Progress Questionnaire - Safety In The City
description: This was survey sent to the Insight Community in conjunction with a telephone survey performed to gauge residents thoughts on the City and how they think about their city. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=182&as=yN1J0gu9Dz&t=1. Open from January 26 - February 04, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2215 Insight Community Members. 1127 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 51%. A total of 1284 respondents completed the survey: 1127 Insight Community Members and 157 using the Open link.

name: Parks Communication - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the first October  2014 Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=109&t=1. Open from Oct 13 - 21, 2014. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 1639 Insight Community Members. 898 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 55%. A total of 1146 respondents completed the survey: 898 Insight Community Members and 248 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

name: Edmontonians' Perception Survey - City Design And Attractiveness
description:
In 2014, the City of Edmonton contracted Leger to conduct a survey of Edmontonians designed to understand perceptions on key measures relating to the quality of life in Edmonton.

This research is aimed at capturing citizen perception based performance measures which feed into the corporate performance reporting to achieve the City’s vision for 2040 (The Way Ahead). In recent years, Citizen Perception Surveys have been carried out annually to gather data and report on the measures. 

Taking into account the recent modifications in performance measures as well as the focus on continuous improvement, the 2014 research was designed to: 
- Measure the progress with respect to the key performance measures
- Understand the drivers of the performance measures and provide recommendations about how the measures can be further improved.
- Make comparisons with past measures wherever applicable

name: 2009 Census - Dwelling Unit By Structure Type And Occupancy (Citywide)
description:
All Census information is as of April 1, 2009.
No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city-, ward- and neighbourhood-level only.
The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.
Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information can not be obtained (i.e. information is not available or can not be released by the facility administration).
“Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
An Unoccupied site is one that was vacant (i.e. no one was living in the unit on April 1), had no structure, was under construction, or was no longer in use (structure existed, but was no longer used as a residence).
purpose: Census information is used by every municipal department, as well as a wide variety of external agencies, to assist with the planning and delivery of programs and services for the citizens of Edmonton.  This report shows the number of households in the region, grouped by the type of structure and the occupancy of the unit.

description: This was one single topic among many as part of the December Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=141&t=1. Open from November 30 - December 09, 2014. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2035 Insight Community Members. 950 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 47%. A total of 1049 respondents completed the survey: 950 Insight Community Members and 99 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

name: 2012 Census - Population By Mode Of Transportation (Ward)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2012. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2012. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=476&as=Hp0xa33UD7&t=1. Open from August 10 - 18, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 3275 Insight Community Members. 1329 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 41%. A total of 1442  respondents completed the survey: 1329 Insight Community Members and 113 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

name: Drainage - Pump Stations
description:
The location of Pump Stations in the City of Edmonton. A Pump Station is a mechanism that raises or lifts water from a lower elevation to a higher elevation.

The City of Edmonton provides this information based on the records retained by the City of Edmonton with respect to the matters.  The City of Edmonton provides no warranty or representation as to whether the information is correct, accurate or free from error and whether it is otherwise suitable for your use or purpose.

name: 2014 Census - Population By Mode Of Transportation (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

columns.description: Number of individuals

name: Accessibility and Disabled Parking - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the January Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=185&t=1. Open from January 11 - 20, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2159 Insight Community Members. 1070 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 50%. A total of 1178 respondents completed the survey: 1070 Insight Community Members and 108 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=526&as=7YW63mx6N7&t=1. Open from September 08 - 16, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 3516 Insight Community Members. 1477 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 42%. columns.name: q5_budgetcycle
columns.description:
Single response question. The City of Edmonton has two separate budgets: 1. The operating budget sets the revenue and spending levels for all of Edmonton's civic services and programs. 2. The capital budget sets the investment required to build, maintain and repair City infrastructure.
We'd like to ask a few questions to understand how much you know about City budgets. In 2014 and before, the City of Edmonton planned its operating budget as a _____ budget. || Possible Answers: one-year/two-year/three-year/four-year/I don't know

name: 2014 Census - Dwelling Unit By Structure Type (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: 2012 Census - Population By School Residency (Ward)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2012. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: City of Edmonton/NAIT Solar Panel Reference System - Per Module Energy Production
description:
The reference system consists of six PV modules arranged at fixed angles on the roof of the Shaw Theatre at NAIT’s Main Campus, near the corner of Princess Elizabeth Avenue and 106 Street. The angles correspond to those typically used for solar installations in Edmonton. Each of the six modules is paired with a duplicate module placed at exactly the same angle. During the winter months, snow will be cleared from the left side of the modules. By pairing modules at exactly the same angles, researchers will be able to compare the effect of snow clearing versus snow cover on energy production. The degree angle of rows are 90, 53, 45, 27, 18, 14 degrees. You can find the actual picture at the "About" tab. In the dataset column name, 90_LEFT means the left panel and 90 degree angle and so on.

 The City is not the owner of this data, it is provided to us and owned by NAIT

name: 2009 Census - Dwelling Unit By Structure Type And Occupancy (Ward)
description:
All Census information is as of April 1, 2009.
Ward Reports are based on the 6-Ward system, which existed in the City of Edmonton until October, 2010.
No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city-, ward- and neighbourhood-level only.
The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.
Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information can not be obtained (i.e. information is not available or can not be released by the facility administration).
“Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.)
An Unoccupied site is one that was vacant (i.e. no one was living in the unit on April 1), had no structure, was under construction, or was no longer in use (structure existed, but was no longer used as a residence).
purpose: Census information is used by every municipal department, as well as a wide variety of external agencies, to assist with the planning and delivery of programs and services for the citizens of Edmonton.  This report shows the number of households in the region, grouped by the type of structure and the occupancy of the unit.

columns.name: ward
columns.description: Ward Reports are based on the 6-Ward system, which existed in the City of Edmonton until October, 2010.

columns.name: structure_type
columns.description: Type of building structure of each household unit.

columns.name: occupied
columns.description: Number of household units that were occupied on April 1, 2009.

columns.name: unoccupied
columns.description: Number of household units that were not occupied on April 1, 2009 (vacant, under construction, no longer in use).

columns.name: no_response
columns.description: Number of household units where the Occupancy information was not available.

name: Front Yards In Bloom Summary
description:
Outlines the progression of Front Yards in Bloom since starting in 1999. Front Yards in Bloom (FYinB) is supported by the City of Edmonton, Edmonton Horticultural Society and postal workers.
Data prior to 2007 is estimated.
purpose: Outlines the progression of Front Yards in Bloom since starting in 1999.

columns.name: year
columns.description: Year of the Front Yards in Bloom program. Nominations are received by early July and delivered to addresses through July and August (judging at the same time).

columns.name: nominations
columns.description: Unique nominations submitted to Front Yards in Bloom per year. This includes multiple nominations for the same address and multiple nominations by a nominator.

columns.name: nominators
columns.description: Unique nominator names. This number is approximate. Estimated variance could be +/- 5%.

columns.name: addresses
columns.description:
Number of unique addresses nominated (by nominators) during one year of Front Yards in Bloom.
This number is approximate. Variance estimated +/- 5%.

columns.name: neighbourhood with nominations
columns.description: Number of neighbourhoods where at least one address received a nomination.

columns.name: partner community leagues
columns.description: Number of community leagues who partnered with the Front Yards in Bloom program. Partnership includes delivering & congratulating addresses in their area. Possibly also local awards and encouraging local nominations.

columns.name: partners neighbourhoods
columns.description: Number of neighbourhoods represented by the Community Leagues who partnered with Front Yards in Bloom. In some cases, one community league may represent more than one neighboruhood.

columns.name: votes to readers choice
columns.description: Number of votes received by the Edmonton Journal towards the Readers' Choice Award. Tabulation of this award is managed entirely by the Edmonton Journal (exact parameters of these votes is unknown).

name: LRT Elevator/Escalator Outages
description: A near-real-time (updated every 5 minutes) list of Elevators and/or Escalators, located in the LRT network, that have a current operational status of Out of Service.
purpose: To provide a list of Out of Service devices (elevators and escalators) that are found in the LRT network.

columns.name: device op status code
columns.description: The operational status code for the device.  1 = Out of Service 0 = In Service

columns.name: device op status
columns.description: The operational status of the device

columns.name: device type
columns.description: The type of device (escalator or elevator)

columns.name: device id
columns.description: The unique ID assigned to the device

columns.name: lrt station id
columns.description: Three letter abbreviation/code assigned to the LRT station

columns.name: lrt station name
columns.description: Name of the LRT station

columns.name: lrt route
columns.description: The LRT line/route that the device can be found on

columns.name: lrt stop
columns.description: The LRT stop that the device can be found at

columns.name: lrt device location
columns.description: A brief description of where the device can be located at the LRT Stop and LRT Route

columns.name: since time stamp
columns.description: The date and time of when the Device went Out of Service

columns.name: polled time stamp
columns.description: The date and time that the Op Status for the Device was last updated.

name: 2009 Census - Dwelling Unit By Structure Type And Ownership (Citywide)
description:
All Census information is as of April 1, 2009.
No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city-, ward- and neighbourhood-level only.
The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.
Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information can not be obtained (i.e. information is not available or can not be released by the facility administration).
“Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Census information is used by every municipal department, as well as a wide variety of external agencies, to assist with the planning and delivery of programs and services for the citizens of Edmonton.  This report shows the number of households in the region, grouped by the type of structure and whether the unit is owned or rented.

name: 2014 Census - Dwelling Units By Structure Type And Occupancy (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: City Engagement - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the March Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=219&t=1. Open from March 9 - 17, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2351 Insight Community Members. 1137 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 48%. A total of 1205 respondents completed the survey: 1137 Insight Community Members and 68 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

name: Property Assessment February 2015 - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the February Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=193&t=1. Open from February 9 - 17, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2302 Insight Community Members. 1021 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 44%. A total of 1205 respondents completed the survey: 1137 Insight Community Members and 68 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

name: 2014 Census - Population By Length Of Residence (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only. Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected. The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available. Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information cannot be obtained (i.e. information is not available or cannot be released by the facility administration).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: 24 Hour Storm Severity Ratings
description:
Rainfall is measured to assess storms and their effects on flooding and sewer performance and design. Rainfall location color icons indicate rainfall totals and maximum storm rating during the past 24 hours. Data is sent once 2mm is accumulated in each gauge, so timing will vary.

Website is updated every 15 minutes . Higher storm ratings and rainfall totals may have occurred if a storm lasts more than 24h. Storm ratings and rainfall are based on data at the gauge location only - nearby areas may experience differing conditions due to variability of rainstorms. Rainfall is measured between May and October; snowfall is not measured.
purpose: To provide the severity rating for rain fall accumulated at a particular City location.

name: Edmontonians' Perception Survey - Access to Amenities and Services that Improve Quality of Life
description:
In 2014, the City of Edmonton contracted Leger to conduct a survey of Edmontonians designed to understand perceptions on key measures relating to the quality of life in Edmonton.

This research is aimed at capturing citizen perception based performance measures which feed into the corporate performance reporting to achieve the City’s vision for 2040 (The Way Ahead). In recent years, Citizen Perception Surveys have been carried out annually to gather data and report on the measures. 

Taking into account the recent modifications in performance measures as well as the focus on continuous improvement, the 2014 research was designed to: 
- Measure the progress with respect to the key performance measures
- Understand the drivers of the performance measures and provide recommendations about how the measures can be further improved.
- Make comparisons with past measures wherever applicable

name: 2014 Census - Dwelling Unit By City Resource Access (Ward)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014.  Ages of residents are effective April 1, 2014.  No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information cannot be obtained (i.e. information is not available or cannot be released by the facility administration).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

columns.name: ward
columns.description: City Ward Number

columns.name: city_resource_access
columns.description: Method used to Access City Resources

columns.name: dwellings
columns.description: Number of Units

name: 2012 Census - Dwelling Unit Status (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2012. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).

name: Graffiti - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the July 2014 Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=46&t=1. Open from July 08 - 20, 2014. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 846 Insight Community Members. 662 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 78%. A total of 705 respondents completed the survey: 662 Insight Community Members and 43 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

name: Community in Bloom - Past Results
description: Results given to Edmonton by the Communities in Bloom national program.
purpose: Awards given to Edmonton by the Communities in Bloom national program since 1996

columns.name: year
columns.description: Year of competition/participation in Communities in Bloom. (1995 was the first year of Communities in Bloom.)

columns.name: category
columns.description: Category of competition/participation for overall awards. (Municipalities may participate in more than one Special Award and/or Outstanding Achievement Award.)

columns.name: evaluated
columns.description: Evaluated or non-evaluated participation. (Municipalities may participate as non-evaluated municipalities, competitive or non-competitive.)

columns.name: rating
columns.description: Bloom rating is out of 5 blooms. This rating is based on judges' scores across all evaluation criteria (environmental action, community involvement, urban forestry, landscapes, natural and cultural heritage, floral displays).

columns.name: special_mention
columns.description: One element of special mention by the national judges. Each evaluated municipality receives special mention for one element in the municipality.

columns.name: category_results
columns.description: Winning status as determined by the national judges.

columns.name: special_awards
columns.description: Special and/or outstanding awards presented to Edmonton. Municipalities may apply for more than one award for each year. These awards are presented to municipalities of any population size. Each award is sponsored.

columns.name: host_location
columns.description: Location of the national awards and National Symposium.

columns.name: national_judges
columns.description: National judges who evaluated Edmonton during their visit. Judges are volunteers who organized and assigned by Communities in Bloom.

columns.name: council_representative
columns.description: Councillor who met with the national judges and presented Edmonton's contributions to the national program.

name: 2014 Census - Dwelling Unit By City Resource Access (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014.  Ages of residents are effective April 1, 2014.  No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information cannot be obtained (i.e. information is not available or cannot be released by the facility administration).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: Intersection Safety Device Locations
description:
This dataset represents the approximate drive lane(s) and the direction of enforcement, of intersections where Intersection Safety Devices are operational.  Intersection Safety Devices enforce red light infractions and speed on green infractions.

Note:  To avoid some confusion of location, efforts were made to shift the geo-location to one side or the other side of a roadway to more clearly indicate the lane(s) of travel and direction of travel and set back from the actual intersection.

Please refer to the FAQ the City has available in regards to Photo Enforcement.

https://www.edmonton.ca/transportation/Mobile_Photo_Enforcement_FAQ.pdf
purpose: To share and to make the public aware of the intersections where Intersection Safety Devices operate and any corresponding attributes associated to the Enforcement and intersection.

columns.name: site id
columns.description: System generated, unique identifier associated with the intersection where enforcement is being conducted.

columns.name: approach
columns.description: The road of travel being driven on that approaches the intersection.

columns.name: cross street
columns.description: The road being crossed at the intersection.

columns.name: travel direction
columns.description: The direction of travel on the Approach road, which crosses the Cross Street at the intersection.

columns.name: posted speed
columns.description: The speed limit of the Approach road, at the intersection of enforcement (km/h).

name: Social Media - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the August 2014 Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=76&t=1. Open from Aug 19 - 25, 2014. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 1029 Insight Community Members. 646 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 63%. A total of 816 respondents completed the survey: 646 Insight Community Members and 170 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only. Neighbourhood results with a population under 50 are not posted to protect the information collected. purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: Edmonton Area Air Quality Readings (Historical)
description:
This dataset provides historical parameter values for stations in the Edmonton Region as determined by the Alberta Capital Airshed.

The data is collected via a web service provided by the Alberta Environmental Monitoring, Evaluation & Reporting Information Service (AEMERIS).

AEMERIS is an initial information-sharing platform designed to provide access to data on key ambient air, water, land and biodiversity indicators and related provincial environmental information and reporting data.
purpose: To provide historical parameter values for air monitoring stations.

name: 2014 Census - Population By School Residency (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: 2014 Census - Dwelling Units By Structure Type And Ownership (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014.  Ages of residents are effective April 1, 2014.  No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information cannot be obtained (i.e. information is not available or cannot be released by the facility administration).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: Rainbow Crosswalk - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the June 2015 Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=325&t=1. Open from June 08 - 16, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2834 Insight Community Members. 1297 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 46%. name: Measuring Progress Questionnaire - City Design And Attractiveness
description: This was survey sent to the Insight Community in conjunction with a telephone survey performed to gauge residents thoughts on the City and how they think about their city. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=182&as=yN1J0gu9Dz&t=1. Open from January 26 - February 04, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2215 Insight Community Members. 1127 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 51%. A total of 1284 respondents completed the survey: 1127 Insight Community Members and 157 using the Open link.

The location of Inlet-Outlets in the City of Edmonton. An Inlet-Outlet is a drainage facility through which stormwater enters or exits a stormwater managed feature.

The City of Edmonton provides no warranty or representation as to whether the information is correct, accurate or free from error and whether it is otherwise suitable for your use or purpose.

name: 2012 Census - Population By School Residency (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2012. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: ETS Bus Schedule GTFS Data Feed - Stop Times (With Datetime Type)
description: This dataset lists the times that a vehicle arrives at and departs from individual stops for each trip in Edmonton.
purpose: To provide a list of all bus stop arrival and departue time in Edmonton

name: 2014 Census - Population By Structure Type And Length Of Residence (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014.  Ages of residents are effective April 1, 2014.  No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information cannot be obtained (i.e. information is not available or cannot be released by the facility administration).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges. With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

Bulk-count data from multiple-resident facilities (such as group homes, transient drop-in centres, residential hotels or criminal detention centres) may be limited when personal information cannot be obtained (i.e. information is not available or cannot be released by the facility administration).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: Edmontonians' Perception Survey - Volunteerism
description:
In 2014, the City of Edmonton contracted Leger to conduct a survey of Edmontonians designed to understand perceptions on key measures relating to the quality of life in Edmonton.

This research is aimed at capturing citizen perception based performance measures which feed into the corporate performance reporting to achieve the City’s vision for 2040 (The Way Ahead). In recent years, Citizen Perception Surveys have been carried out annually to gather data and report on the measures. 

Taking into account the recent modifications in performance measures as well as the focus on continuous improvement, the 2014 research was designed to: 
- Measure the progress with respect to the key performance measures
- Understand the drivers of the performance measures and provide recommendations about how the measures can be further improved.
- Make comparisons with past measures wherever applicable

name: 2014 Census - Population By Mode Of Transportation (Ward)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).

name: 2014 Census - Population By Employment Status (Citywide)
description: All Census information is as of April 1, 2014. No data on any individual residence will be released.  To protect the privacy of individuals, data is compiled and presented at the city, ward and neighbourhood level only.  Neighbourhood results with a population under 49 are not posted to protect the information collected.  The designation of “No Response” includes households from which no census data could be collected or only partial data was available.  “Other Residential” includes dwelling units not covered by the other categories, such as a unit attached to a non-residential structure (e.g. an apartment in a store or church) or a movable structure (e.g. recreational vehicle, tent, etc.).
purpose: Current, reliable census data is an essential tool available to the City of Edmonton, and all census data consumers, that will enable them to meet current and future challenges.  The data allows consumers to anticipate and adapt to change.  Basing decisions on constantly updated demographics results in more appropriate use of revenue and resources, allowing consumers to be proactive in their response to multiple demands, shifts in priorities and rapid changes that the future will bring.  With changes being made to collection of federal census data, consistent collection of municipal census data will be the most reliable source of comparative data available to the City of Edmonton.  Current census data will also allow the City to maximize per capita grants provided by the provincial and federal governments.

name: All Photo Enforcement Zone Centre Points
description:
This dataset represents the centre points of each Zone or Operational Area where Photo Enforcement is conducted.  An enforcement unit can be found anywhere along the area of the Zone, thus the actual range of enforcement would extend beyond the indicated area of the zone.  The centre points are extracted for mapping purposes only and are not intended to imply or suggest that is where the Photo Enforcement is being conducted.  Designated Zones are continuously reviewed, revised, added, removed and otherwise updated in accordance to the guidelines for establishing a Zone for photo enforcement.

Please refer to the FAQ the City has available in regards to Photo Enforcement.

https://www.edmonton.ca/transportation/Mobile_Photo_Enforcement_FAQ.pdf
purpose: To share and to make the public aware of the Zones where Photo Enforcement can operate and the corresponding attributes associated to the Zone.

columns.name: location description
columns.description: A description of where along the Road Name that the enforcement zone is located

columns.name: speed limit
columns.description: A speed limit that is being monitored and enforced (km/h)

name: New Years Eve Downtown - Edmonton Insight Community
description: This was one single topic among many as part of the August 2015 Mixed Topic survey. Test link to view these questions: https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/R.aspx?a=476&as=Hp0xa33UD7&t=1. Open from August 10 - 18, 2015. At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 3275 Insight Community Members. 1329 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 41%. A total of 1442  respondents completed the survey: 1329 Insight Community Members and 113 using the anonymous link which will have no demographic info.

At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 2215 Insight Community Members. 1127 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 51%.
